I have been using JUnit 3.7 for a couple of months now, and
have run accross something very frustrating.  We (the Apache
Avalon project) use Ant to do our builds and automated testing,
however the behavior for test collection is different based
on wether a Test is a TestCase or a TestSuite.

Your FAQ suggests that for one-time setup code you need to run
it in a TestSuite.  The problem is this, we have an abstract
TestCase that takes a configuration file and sets up a standard
environment and several testcases written against it.  I want
to make the environment to be built once for each TestCase.
I can't simply change the class I extend to TestSuite because
TestSuite does not inherit Assert.  Doing that requires modifying
a large number of tests that are already written.

Instead, I had to do _alot_ of hackery to force my tests to be
run once and respect the run-once code.

In order to make my life easier, and other people's life easier
you should do one of two things:

* allow TestSuite to inherit Assert, or
* define a marker interface that runs a test AS IS (no automatic
  dumping into a TestSuite).

I guess another alternative is to change the behavior of TestSuite
to invoke only one class per TestCase, and merely iterate over the
public "test" methods.  Currently, TestSuite instantiates a whole
new class for *each* method invokation.  This is IMO wasteful--and
breaks common understandings of how a class works.
